introduct and analysi 

the republ of plato is the longest of hi work with the except 
of the law and is certainli the greatest of them there are nearer 
approach to modern metaphi in the philebu and in the sophist the 
politicu or statesman is more ideal the form and institut of 
the state are more clearli drawn out in the law a work of art the 
symposium and the protagora are of higher excel but no other 
dialogu of plato ha the same larg of view and the same perfect 
of style no other show an equal knowledg of the world or contain 
more of those thought which are new a well a old and not of one age 
onli but of all nowher in plato is there a deeper ironi or a greater 
wealth of humour or imageri or more dramat power nor in ani other of 
hi write is the attempt made to interweav life and specul or 
to connect polit with philosophi the republ is the centr around 
which the other dialogu may be group here philosophi reach the 
highest point cp especi in book v vi vii to which ancient 
thinker ever attain plato among the greek like bacon among the 
modern wa the first who conceiv a method of knowledg although 
neither of them alway distinguish the bare outlin or form from 
the substanc of truth and both of them had to be content with an 
abstract of scienc which wa not yet realiz he wa the greatest 
metaphi geniu whom the world ha seen and in him more than in 
ani other ancient thinker the germ of futur knowledg are contain 
the scienc of logic and psycholog which have suppli so mani 
instrument of thought to after age are base upon the analysi 
of socrat and plato the principl of definit the law of 
contradict the fallaci of argu in a circl the distinct 
between the essenc and accid of a thing or notion between mean 
and end between cau and condit also the divi of the mind 
into the ration concupisc and irasc element or of pleasur 
and desir into necessari and unnecessari these and other great 
form of thought are all of them to be found in the republ and were 
probabl first invent by plato the greatest of all logic truth 
and the one of which writer on philosophi are most apt to lose sight 
the differ between word and thing ha been most strenuou 
insist on by him cp rep polit cratyl although he ha not 
alway avoid the confu of them in hi own write e g rep 
but he doe not bind up truth in logic formula logic is still 
veil in metaphi and the scienc which he imago to contempl 
all truth and all exist is veri unlik the doctrin of the 
syllog which aristotl claim to have discov soph elenchi 

neither must we forget that the republ is but the third part of a 
still larger design which wa to have includ an ideal histori of 
athen a well a a polit and physic philosophi the fragment of 
the critia ha given birth to a world famou fiction second onli in 
import to the tale of troy and the legend of arthur and is said a 
a fact to have inspir some of the earli navig of the sixteenth 
centuri thi mythic tale of which the subject wa a histori of the 
war of the athenian against the island of atlanti is suppo to be 
found upon an unfinish poem of solon to which it would have stood 
in the same relat a the write of the logograph to the poem of 
homer it would have told of a struggl for liberti cp tim intend 
to repr the conflict of persia and hella we may judg from the 
nobl commenc of the timaeu from the fragment of the critia 
itself and from the third book of the law in what manner plato would 
have treat thi high argument we can onli guess whi the great design 
wa abandon perhap becau plato becam sensibl of some incongru 
in a fictiti histori or becau he had lost hi interest in it or 
becau advanc year forbad the complet of it and we may plea 
ourselv with the fanci that had thi imaginari narr ever been 
finish we should have found plato himself sympathi with the 
struggl for hellen independ cp law sing a hymn of triumph 
over marathon and salami perhap make the reflect of herodotu 
where he contempl the growth of the athenian empir how brave a 
thing is freedom of speech which ha made the athenian so far 
exceed everi other state of hella in great or more probabl 
attribut the victori to the ancient good order of athen and to the 
favor of apollo and athen cp introd to critia 

again plato may be regard a the captain arhchegoz or leader 
of a goodli band of follow for in the republ is to be found the 
origin of cicero s de republica of st augustin s citi of god 
of the utopia of sir thoma more and of the numer other imaginari 
state which are frame upon the same model the extent to which 
aristotl or the aristotelian school were indebt to him in the 
polit ha been littl recogni and the recognit is the 
more necessari becau it is not made by aristotl himself the two 
philosoph had more in common than they were consciou of and 
probabl some element of plato remain still undetect in aristotl in 
english philosophi too mani affin may be trace not onli in the 
work of the cambridg platonist but in great origin writer like 
berkeley or coleridg to plato and hi idea that there is a truth 
higher than experi of which the mind bear wit to herself is 
a convict which in our own gener ha been enthusiast 
assert and is perhap gain ground of the greek author who at the 
renaiss brought a new life into the world plato ha had the greatest 
influenc the republ of plato is also the first treati upon 
educ of which the write of milton and lock rousseau jean 
paul and goeth are the legitim descend like dant or bunyan 
he ha a revel of anoth life like bacon he is profoundli 
impress with the uniti of knowledg in the earli church he exerci 
a real influenc on theolog and at the reviv of literatur on 
polit even the fragment of hi word when repeat at second hand 
symp have in all age ravish the heart of men who have seen 
reflect in them their own higher natur he is the father of ideal 
in philosophi in polit in literatur and mani of the latest 
concept of modern thinker and statesman such a the uniti of 
knowledg the reign of law and the equal of the sex have been 
anticip in a dream by him 

the argument of the republ is the search after justic the natur 
of which is first hint at by cephalu the just and blameless old 
man then discu on the basi of proverbi moral by socrat and 
polemarchu then caricatur by thrasymachu and partial explain 
by socrat reduc to an abstract by glaucon and adeimantu and 
have becom invi in the individu reappear at length in the 
ideal state which is construct by socrat the first care of the 
ruler is to be educ of which an outlin is drawn after the old 
hellen model provid onli for an improv religion and moral 
and more simplic in music and gymnast a manlier strain of poetri 
and greater harmoni of the individu and the state we are thu led on 
to the concept of a higher state in which no man call anyth hi 
own and in which there is neither marri nor give in marriag 
and king are philosoph and philosoph are king and there 
is anoth and higher educ intellectu a well a moral and 
religi of scienc a well a of art and not of youth onli but of 
the whole of life such a state is hardli to be realiz in thi world 
and quickli degen to the perfect ideal succ the govern 
of the soldier and the lover of honour thi again declin into 
democraci and democraci into tyranni in an imaginari but regular order 
have not much resembl to the actual fact when the wheel ha 
come full circl we do not begin again with a new period of human life 
but we have pa from the best to the worst and there we end the 
subject is then chang and the old quarrel of poetri and philosophi 
which had been more lightli treat in the earlier book of the republ 
is now resum and fought out to a conclu poetri is discov to 
be an imit thrice remov from the truth and homer a well a 
the dramat poet have been condemn a an imit is sent into 
banish along with them and the idea of the state is supplement by 
the revel of a futur life 

the divi into book like all similar divi cp sir g c lewi 
in the classic museum is probabl later than the age of plato the 
natur divi are five in number 1 book i and the first half 
of book ii down to the paragraph begin i had alway admir the 
geniu of glaucon and adeimantu which is introductori the first 
book contain a refut of the popular and sophist notion of 
justic and conclud like some of the earlier dialogu without 
arriv at ani definit result to thi is append a restat of 
the natur of justic accord to common opinion and an answer is 
demand to the question what is justic strip of appear the 
second divi 2 includ the remaind of the second and the whole 
of the third and fourth book which are mainli occupi with the 
construct of the first state and the first educ the third 
divi 3 consist of the fifth sixth and seventh book in which 
philosophi rather than justic is the subject of enquiri and the 
second state is construct on principl of commun and rule by 
philosoph and the contempl of the idea of good take the place 
of the social and polit virtu in the eighth and ninth book 4 
the perver of state and of the individu who correspond to them 
are review in success and the natur of pleasur and the principl 
of tyranni are further anali in the individu man the tenth book 
5 is the conclu of the whole in which the relat of philosophi 
to poetri are final determin and the happi of the citizen 
in thi life which ha now been assur is crown by the vision of 
anoth 

or a more gener divi into two part may be adopt the first 
book i iv contain the descript of a state frame gener in 
accord with hellen notion of religion and moral while in the 
second book v x the hellen state is transform into an 
ideal kingdom of philosophi of which all other govern are the 
perver these two point of view are realli oppo and the 
opposit is onli veil by the geniu of plato the republ like 
the phaedru see introduct to phaedru is an imperfect whole the 
higher light of philosophi break through the regular of the 
hellen templ which at last fade away into the heaven whether thi 
imperfect of structur ari from an enlarg of the plan 
or from the imperfect reconcil in the writer s own mind of the 
struggl element of thought which are now first brought togeth 
by him or perhap from the composit of the work at differ 
time are question like the similar question about the iliad and 
the odyssey which are worth ask but which cannot have a distinct 
answer in the age of plato there wa no regular mode of public 
and an author would have the le scrupl in alter or ad to a 
work which wa known onli to a few of hi friend there is no absurd 
in suppo that he may have laid hi labour asid for a time or 
turn from one work to anoth and such interrupt would be more 
like to occur in the case of a long than of a short write in all 
attempt to determin the chronolog order of the platon write 
on intern evid thi uncertainti about ani singl dialogu be 
compo at one time is a disturb element which must be admit 
to affect longer work such a the republ and the law more than 
shorter one but on the other hand the seem discrep of 
the republ may onli ari out of the discord element which the 
philosoph ha attempt to unit in a singl whole perhap without 
be himself abl to recogni the inconsist which is obviou to 
u for there is a judgment of after age which few great writer have 
ever been abl to anticip for themselv they do not perceiv the 
want of connexion in their own write or the gap in their system 
which are visibl enough to those who come after them in the begin 
of literatur and philosophi amid the first effort of thought and 
languag more inconsist occur than now when the path of 
specul are well worn and the mean of word preci defin 
for consist too is the growth of time and some of the greatest 
creation of the human mind have been want in uniti tri by thi 
test sever of the platon dialogu accord to our modern idea 
appear to be defect but the defici is no proof that they were 
compo at differ time or by differ hand and the supposit 
that the republ wa written uninterruptedli and by a continu effort 
is in some degr confirm by the numer refer from one part of 
the work to anoth 

the second titl concern justic is not the one by which the 
republ is quot either by aristotl or gener in antiqu and 
like the other second titl of the platon dialogu may therefor be 
assum to be of later date morgenstern and other have ask 
whether the definit of justic which is the profess aim or the 
construct of the state is the princip argument of the work the 
answer is that the two blend in one and are two face of the same 
truth for justic is the order of the state and the state is the 
visibl embodi of justic under the condit of human societi the 
one is the soul and the other is the bodi and the greek ideal of the 
state a of the individu is a fair mind in a fair bodi in hegelian 
phraseolog the state is the realiti of which justic is the idea or 
describ in christian languag the kingdom of god is within and yet 
develop into a church or extern kingdom the hou not made with 
hand etern in the heaven is reduc to the proport of an 
earthli build or to use a platon imag justic and the state are 
the warp and the woof which run through the whole textur and when the 
constitut of the state is complet the concept of justic is not 
dismiss but reappear under the same or differ name throughout 
the work both a the inner law of the individu soul and final a 
the principl of reward and punish in anoth life the virtu 
are base on justic of which common honesti in buy and sell 
is the shadow and justic is base on the idea of good which is the 
harmoni of the world and is reflect both in the institut of 
state and in motion of the heavenli bodi cp tim the timaeu 
which take up the polit rather than the ethic side of the 
republ and is chiefli occupi with hypothesi concern the outward 
world yet contain mani indic that the same law is suppo to 
reign over the state over natur and over man 

too much howev ha been made of thi question both in ancient and 
modern time there is a stage of critic in which all work whether 
of natur or of art are refer to design now in ancient write 
and ind in literatur gener there remain often a larg element 
which wa not comprehend in the origin design for the plan grow 
under the author s hand new thought occur to him in the act of 
write he ha not work out the argument to the end befor he begin 
the reader who seek to find some one idea under which the whole may be 
conceiv must necessarili seiz on the vaguest and most gener thu 
stallbaum who is dissatisfi with the ordinari explan of the 
argument of the republ imago himself to have found the true 
argument in the repres of human life in a state perfect by 
justic and govern accord to the idea of good there may be some 
use in such gener descript but they can hardli be said to express 
the design of the writer the truth is that we may a well speak of 
mani design a of one nor need anyth be exclud from the plan of 
a great work to which the mind is natur led by the associ of 
idea and which doe not interf with the gener purpo what kind 
or degr of uniti is to be sought after in a build in the plastic 
art in poetri in prose is a problem which ha to be determin 
rel to the subject matter to plato himself the enquiri what 
wa the intent of the writer or what wa the princip argument 
of the republ would have been hardli intellig and therefor had 
better be at onc dismiss cp the introduct to the phaedru 

is not the republ the vehicl of three or four great truth which 
to plato s own mind are most natur repr in the form of the 
state just a in the jewish prophet the reign of messiah or the day 
of the lord or the suffer servant or peopl of god or the sun of 
righteou with heal in hi wing onli convey to u at least 
their great spiritu ideal so through the greek state plato reveal 
to u hi own thought about divin perfect which is the idea of 
good like the sun in the visibl world about human perfect which 
is justic about educ begin in youth and continu in later 
year about poet and sophist and tyrant who are the fal teacher 
and evil ruler of mankind about the world which is the embodi of 
them about a kingdom which exist nowher upon earth but is laid up 
in heaven to be the pattern and rule of human life no such inspir 
creation is at uniti with itself ani more than the cloud of heaven 
when the sun pierc through them everi shade of light and dark of 
truth and of fiction which is the veil of truth is allow in a work 
of philosoph imagin it is not all on the same plane it easili 
pa from idea to myth and fanci from fact to figur of speech 
it is not prose but poetri at least a great part of it and ought not 
to be judg by the rule of logic or the probabl of histori the 
writer is not fashion hi idea into an artist whole they take 
poss of him and are too much for him we have no need therefor 
to discu whether a state such a plato ha conceiv is practic or 
not or whether the outward form or the inward life came first into the 
mind of the writer for the practic of hi idea ha noth to 
do with their truth and the highest thought to which he attain may be 
truli said to bear the greatest mark of design justic more than the 
extern frame work of the state the idea of good more than justic 
the great scienc of dialect or the organi of idea ha no real 
content but is onli a type of the method or spirit in which the 
higher knowledg is to be pursu by the spectat of all time and 
all exist it is in the fifth sixth and seventh book that plato 
reach the summit of specul and these although they fail to 
satisfi the requir of a modern thinker may therefor be regard 
a the most import a they are also the most origin portion of 
the work 

it is not necessari to discu at length a minor question which ha

and thrasymachu is reduc to silenc at the close of the first book

of thrasymachu 

cephalu the patriarch of the hou ha been appropri engag 
in offer a sacrif he is the pattern of an old man who ha almost 
done with life and is at peac with himself and with all mankind he 
feel that he is draw nearer to the world below and seem to linger 
around the memori of the past he is eager that socrat should come

consciou of a well spent life glad at have escap from the 
tyranni of youth lust hi love of conver hi affect hi 
indiff to rich even hi garrul are interest trait of 
charact he is not one of those who have noth to say becau their 
whole mind ha been absorb in make money yet he acknowledg 
that rich have the advantag of place men abov the temptat 
to dishonesti or falsehood the respect attent shown to him by 
socrat whose love of conver no le than the mission impo 
upon him by the oracl lead him to ask question of all men young and 
old alik should also be note who better suit to rai the question 
of justic than cephalu whose life might seem to be the express of 
it the moder with which old age is pictur by cephalu a a veri 
toler portion of exist is characterist not onli of him 
but of greek feel gener and contrast with the exagg of 
cicero in the de senectut the even of life is describ by plato

cp lysimachu in the lach 

hi son and heir polemarchu ha the frank and impetu of 
youth he is for detain socrat by forc in the open scene 
and will not let him off on the subject of woman and child 
like cephalu he is limit in hi point of view and repr 
the proverbi stage of moral which ha rule of life rather than 
principl and he quot simonid cp aristoph cloud a hi father 
had quot pindar but after thi he ha no more to say the answer 
which he make are onli elicit from him by the dialect of socrat

and adeimantu nor is he sensibl of the necess of refut them he 
belong to the pre socrat or pre dialect age he is incap of 
argu and is bewild by socrat to such a degr that he doe not 
know what he is say he is made to admit that justic is a thief and 
that the virtu follow the analog of the art from hi brother lysia 
contra eratosth we learn that he fell a victim to the thirti tyrant 
but no allu is here made to hi fate nor to the circumst that 
cephalu and hi famili were of syracusan origin and had migrat from 
thurii to athen 

the chalcedonian giant thrasymachu of whom we have alreadi heard

plato s concept of them in some of their worst characterist he 
is vain and bluster refu to discour unless he is paid fond of

insol whether such doctrin a are attribut to him by plato were 
realli held either by him or by ani other sophist is uncertain in the 
infanc of philosophi seriou error about moral might easili grow 
up they are certainli put into the mouth of speaker in thucydid 
but we are concern at present with plato s descript of him and not

determin to cram down their throat or put bodili into their 
soul hi own word elicit a cri of horror from socrat the 
state of hi temper is quit a worthi of remark a the process of the 
argument noth is more amu than hi complet submiss when 
he ha been onc thoroughli beaten at first he seem to continu the

thu in a success of charact plato repr the success

the delin of socrat in the republ is not wholli consist in 
the first book we have more of the real socrat such a he is depict

idea of the real socrat in one passag plato himself seem to 
intim that the time had now come for socrat who had pa hi 
whole life in philosophi to give hi own opinion and not to be alway 
repeat the notion of other men there is no evid that either the 
idea of good or the concept of a perfect state were comprehend in 
the socrat teach though he certainli dwelt on the natur of 
the univ and of final cau cp xen mem phaedo and a deep 
thinker like him in hi thirti or forti year of public teach could 
hardli have fail to touch on the natur of famili relat for 
which there is also some posit evid in the memorabilia mem the

a greek in the age of plato attach no import to the question

either or a compound of both and thi compound is veri attract

which one man play one part onli is not adapt for complex and 
when one of these polyphon pantomim gentleman offer to exhibit 
himself and hi poetri we will show him everi observ of respect 
but at the same time tell him that there is no room for hi kind in our 
state we prefer the rough honest poet and will not depart from our 
origin model law 

next a to the music a song or ode ha three part the subject the 
harmoni and the rhythm of which the two last are depend upon the 
first a we banish strain of lament so we may now banish the 
mix lydian harmoni which are the harmoni of lament and 
a our citizen are to be temper we may also banish convivi 
harmoni such a the ionian and pure lydian two remain the 
dorian and phrygian the first for war the second for peac the 
one express of courag the other of obedi or instruct or 
religi feel and a we reject varieti of harmoni we shall 
also reject the mani string variou shape instrument which give 
utter to them and in particular the flute which is more complex

and the pan s pipe in the field thu we have made a purgat of

harmoni simpl and suitabl to the occa there are four note 
of the tetrachord and there are three ratio of metr 3 2 2 2 
2 1 which have all their characterist and the foot have differ

form of plant and anim 

other artist a well a poet should be warn against mean or

next we pa on to gymnast about which i would remark that the

recov well if they don t there is an end of them wherea the rich

the next question is who are to be our ruler first the elder must

now they will be the best who love their subject most and think that

6 two paradox which strike the modern reader a in the highest degr

book iv adeimantu said suppo a person to argu socrat that you 
make your citizen miser and thi by their own free will they are

and hou and money of their own they live a mercenari and are

mistress well and what answer do you give my answer is that 
our guardian may or may not be the happiest of men i should not be 
surpri to find in the long run that they were but thi is not the 
aim of our constitut which wa design for the good of the whole 
and not of ani one part if i went to a sculptor and blame him for 
have paint the eye which is the noblest featur of the face not

should look at the statu a a whole now i can well imagin a fool s

and fine linen and potter lie on sofa and have their wheel at hand 
that they may work a littl when they plea and cobbler and all the

middl condit is best for artisan they should have money enough to

the same condit be best for our citizen if they are poor they will 
be mean if rich luxuri and lazi and in neither case content 
but then how will our poor citi be abl to go to war against an enemi 
who ha money there may be a difficulti in fight against one enemi 
against two there will be none in the first place the contest will be 
carri on by train warrior against well to do citizen and is not a 
regular athlet an easi match for two stout oppon at least suppo

desir for their own sake in a great trial or danger or temptat

we have alreadi said now dog are not divid into he and she we do

longer care to consid how these idea must be limit in practic or 
harmon with the condit of human life they are full of light 
but the light to them ha becom onli a sort of lumin mist or 
blind almost everi one ha known some enthusiast half educ 
person who see everyth at fal distanc and in erron 
proport 

with thi disord of eyesight may be contrast anoth of those who 
see not far into the distanc but what is near onli who have been 
engag all their life in a trade or a profess who are limit to 
a set or sect of their own men of thi kind have no univ except 
their own interest or the interest of their class no principl but 
the opinion of person like themselv no knowledg of affair beyond 
what they pick up in the street or at their club suppo them to be 
sent into a larger world to undertak some higher call from be

becom philosoph or imagin them on a sudden to receiv an inward 
light which reveal to them for the first time in their life a higher 
idea of god and the exist of a spiritu world by thi sudden 
conver or chang is not their daili life like to be upset and on 
the other hand will not mani of their old prejud and narrow 
still adher to them long after they have begun to take a more 
comprehen view of human thing from familiar exampl like these we 
may learn what plato meant by the eyesight which is liabl to two kind 
of disord 

nor have we ani difficulti in draw a parallel between the young 
athenian in the fifth centuri befor christ who becam unsettl by new 
idea and the student of a modern univ who ha been the subject 
of a similar aufklarung we too observ that when young men begin to 
critici customari belief or to anali the constitut of human 
natur they are apt to lose hold of solid principl greek they are 
like tree which have been frequent transplant the earth about them

upon everi flower follow their own wayward will or becau the 
wind blow them they catch opinion a disea are caught when 
they are in the air born hither and thither they speedili fall

hardli retain the distinct of right and wrong they seem to think one 
thing a good a anoth they suppo themselv to be search after 
truth when they are play the game of follow my leader they fall 
in love at first sight with paradox respect moral some fanci 
about art some novelti or eccentr in religion and like lover 
they are so absorb for a time in their new notion that they can think 
of noth el the resolut of some philosoph or theolog

like the youth in the philebu they are readi to discour to ani one

be count happi if in later year they retain some of the simpl truth 
which they acquir in earli educ and which they may perhap 
find to be worth all the rest such is the pictur which plato draw and 
which we onli reproduc partli in hi own word of the danger which 
beset youth in time of transit when old opinion are fade 
away and the new are not yet firmli establish their condit is 
ingeni compar by him to that of a supposit son who ha 
made the discoveri that hi reput parent are not hi real one and 
in consequ they have lost their author over him

book viii and so we have arriv at the conclu that in the perfect

govern and the individu who answer to them

and other they take their pleasur by stealth like boy who are

and what manner of man answer to such a state in love of content

ill educ yet fond of literatur although not himself a

and now let u set anoth citi over against anoth man the next form

thu much of the origin let u next consid the evil of oligarchi

ha enorm wealth the other is entir destitut but observ that

of both and thi evil state of societi origin in bad educ and 
bad govern 

like state like man the chang in the latter begin with the

next come democraci and the democrat man out of oligarchi and 
the oligarch man insati avar is the rule passion of an

risk but the rule class do not want remedi they care onli for

now there are occa on which the governor and the govern meet

privat impart to hi companion that our peopl are not good for

itself so from the least cau or with none at all the citi fall ill

when the poor are the victor kill some and exil some and give 
equal share in the govern to all the rest 

the manner of life in such a state is that of democrat there is 
freedom and plain of speech and everi man doe what is right in 
hi own eye and ha hi own way of life henc ari the most variou 
develop of charact the state is like a piec of embroideri of

who like woman and child prefer thi varieti to real beauti and

can buy anyth the great charm is that you may do a you like you 
may govern if you like let it alon if you like go to war and make 
peac if you feel dispo and all quit irrespect of anybodi 
el when you condemn men to death they remain aliv all the same a 
gentleman is desir to go into exil and he stalk about the street

how grandli democraci set her foot upon all our fine theori of 
educ how littl she care for the train of her statesman the 
onli qualif which she demand is the profess of patriot

let u now inspect the individu democrat and first a in the case 
of the state we will trace hi antec he is the son of a miserli 
oligarch and ha been taught by him to restrain the love of unnecessari 
pleasur perhap i ought to explain thi latter term necessari 
pleasur are those which are good and which we cannot do without 
unnecessari pleasur are those which do no good and of which the 
desir might be erad by earli train for exampl the pleasur 
of eat and drink are necessari and healthi up to a certain point 
beyond that point they are alik hurt to bodi and mind and the 
excess may be avoid when in excess they may be rightli call 
expen pleasur in opposit to the use one and the drone a 
we call him is the slave of these unnecessari pleasur and desir 
wherea the miserli oligarch is subject onli to the necessari 

the oligarch chang into the democrat in the follow manner the 
youth who ha had a miserli bring up get a tast of the drone s 
honey he meet with wild companion who introduc him to everi new 
pleasur a in the state so in the individu there are alli on 
both side temptat from without and passion from within there is 
reason also and extern influenc of parent and friend in allianc 
with the oligarch principl and the two faction are in violent 
conflict with one anoth sometim the parti of order prevail but 
then again new desir and new disord ari and the whole mob of 
passion get poss of the acropoli that is to say the soul 
which they find void and unguard by true word and work falsehood 
and illu ascend to take their place the prodig go back into 
the countri of the lotophagi or drone and openli dwell there and if 
ani offer of allianc or parley of individu elder come from home 
the fal spirit shut the gate of the castl and permit no one to 
enter there is a battl and they gain the victori and straightway 
make allianc with the desir they banish modesti which they call 
folli and send temper over the border when the hou ha been 
swept and garnish they dress up the exil vice and crown them 
with garland bring them back under new name insol they call good 
breed anarchi freedom wast magnif impud courag such 
is the process by which the youth pa from the necessari pleasur to 
the unnecessari after a while he divid hi time imparti between 
them and perhap when he get older and the violenc of passion 
ha abat he restor some of the exil and life in a sort of 
equilibrium indulg first one pleasur and then anoth and if 
reason come and tell him that some pleasur are good and honour 
and other bad and vile he shake hi head and say that he can make 
no distinct between them thu he life in the fanci of the hour 
sometim he take to drink and then he turn abstain he practi 
in the gymnasium or he doe noth at all then again he would be a 
philosoph or a politician or again he would be a warrior or a man of 
busi he is 

everi thing by start and noth long 

there remain still the finest and fairest of all men and all 
state tyranni and the tyrant tyranni spring from democraci much a 
democraci spring from oligarchi both ari from excess the one from 
excess of wealth the other from excess of freedom the great natur 
good of life say the democrat is freedom and thi exclu love 
of freedom and regardless of everyth el is the cau of the 
chang from democraci to tyranni the state demand the strong wine of 
freedom and unless her ruler give her a plenti draught punish 
and insult them equal and fratern of governor and govern is 
the approv principl anarchi is the law not of the state onli but 
of privat hou and extend even to the anim father and son 
citizen and foreign teacher and pupil old and young are all on a 
level father and teacher fear their son and pupil and the wisdom 
of the young man is a match for the elder and the old imit the 
jaunti manner of the young becau they are afraid of be thought 
moro slave are on a level with their master and mistress and 
there is no differ between men and woman nay the veri anim in 
a democrat state have a freedom which is unknown in other place the 
she dog are a good a their she mistress and hor and as march 
along with digniti and run their nose against anybodi who come in 
their way that ha often been my experi at last the citizen 
becom so sensit that they cannot endur the yoke of law written or 
unwritten they would have no man call himself their master such is the 
gloriou begin of thing out of which tyranni spring gloriou 
ind but what is to follow the ruin of oligarchi is the ruin of 
democraci for there is a law of contrari the excess of freedom 
pa into the excess of slaveri and the greater the freedom the 
greater the slaveri you will rememb that in the oligarchi were found 
two class rogu and pauper whom we compar to drone with and 
without sting these two class are to the state what phlegm and bile 
are to the human bodi and the state physician or legisl must get 
rid of them just a the bee master keep the drone out of the hive 
now in a democraci too there are drone but they are more numer 
and more danger than in the oligarchi there they are inert and 
unpracti here they are full of life and anim and the keener 
sort speak and act while the other buzz about the bema and prevent 
their oppon from be heard and there is anoth class in 
democrat state of respect thrive individu who can be 
squeez when the drone have need of their poss there is 
moreov a third class who are the labour and the artisan and 
they make up the mass of the peopl when the peopl meet they 
are omnipot but they cannot be brought togeth unless they are 
attract by a littl honey and the rich are made to suppli the honey 
of which the demagogu keep the greater part themselv give a tast 
onli to the mob their victim attempt to resist they are driven mad 
by the sting of the drone and so becom downright oligarch in 
self defenc then follow inform and convict for treason the 
peopl have some protector whom they nur into great and from thi 
root the tree of tyranni spring the natur of the chang is indic 
in the old fabl of the templ of zeu lycaeu which tell how he who 
tast human flesh mix up with the flesh of other victim will turn 
into a wolf even so the protector who tast human blood and slay 
some and exil other with or without law who hint at abolit of 
debt and divi of land must either perish or becom a wolf that 
is a tyrant perhap he is driven out but he soon come back from 
exil and then if hi enemi cannot get rid of him by law mean 
they plot hi assassin thereupon the friend of the peopl make 
hi well known request to them for a bodi guard which they readili 
grant think onli of hi danger and not of their own now let the 
rich man make to himself wing for he will never run away again if he 
doe not do so then and the great protector have crush all hi 
rival stand proudli erect in the chariot of state a full blown 
tyrant let u enquir into the natur of hi happi 

in the earli day of hi tyranni he smile and beam upon everybodi he 
is not a dominu no not he he ha onli come to put an end to debt 
and the monopoli of land have got rid of foreign enemi he make 
himself necessari to the state by alway go to war he is thu 
enabl to depress the poor by heavi tax and so keep them at work 
and he can get rid of bolder spirit by hand them over to the enemi 
then come unpopular some of hi old associ have the courag to 
oppo him the consequ is that he ha to make a purgat of the 
state but unlik the physician who purg away the bad he must get 
rid of the high spirit the wise and the wealthi for he ha no choic 
between death and a life of shame and dishonour and the more hate he 
is the more he will requir trusti guard but how will he obtain them 
they will come flock like bird for pay will he not rather obtain 
them on the spot he will take the slave from their owner and make 
them hi bodi guard these are hi trust friend who admir and 
look up to him are not the tragic poet wise who magnifi and exalt the 
tyrant and say that he is wise by associ with the wise and are 
not their prai of tyranni alon a suffici reason whi we should 
exclud them from our state they may go to other citi and gather the 
mob about them with fine word and chang commonwealth into tyranni 
and democraci receiv honour and reward for their servic but 
the higher they and their friend ascend constitut hill the more 
their honour will fail and becom too asthmat to mount to return to 
the tyrant how will he support that rare armi of hi first by rob 
the templ of their treasur which will enabl him to lighten the 
tax then he will take all hi father s properti and spend it on 
hi companion male or femal now hi father is the demu and if the 
demu get angri and say that a great hulk son ought not to be a 
burden on hi parent and bid him and hi riotou crew begon then 
will the parent know what a monster he ha been nurtur and that the 
son whom he would fain expel is too strong for him you do not mean to 
say that he will beat hi father ye he will after have taken away 
hi arm then he is a parricid and a cruel unnatur son and the 
peopl have jump from the fear of slaveri into slaveri out of the 
smoke into the fire thu liberti when out of all order and reason 
pa into the worst form of servitud 

in the previou book plato ha describ the ideal state now he 
return to the pervert or declin form on which he had lightli 
touch at the end of book iv these he describ in a success of 
parallel between the individu and the state trace the origin of 
either in the state or individu which ha prece them he begin 
by ask the point at which he digress and is thu led shortli to 
recapitul the substanc of the three former book which also contain 
a parallel of the philosoph and the state 

of the first declin he give no intellig account he would not have 
like to admit the most probabl cau of the fall of hi ideal state 
which to u would appear to be the impract of commun or the 
natur antagon of the rule and subject class he throw a 
veil of mysteri over the origin of the declin which he attribut to 
ignor of the law of popul of thi law the famou geometr 
figur or number is the express like the ancient in gener he had 
no idea of the gradual perfect of man or of the educ of the 
human race hi ideal wa not to be attain in the cour of age but 
wa to spring in full armour from the head of the legisl when good 
law had been given he thought onli of the manner in which they were 
like to be corrupt or of how they might be fill up in detail or 
restor in accord with their origin spirit he appear not to 
have reflect upon the full mean of hi own word in the brief 
space of human life noth great can be accomplish or again a he 
afterward say in the law infinit time is the maker of citi the 
order of constitut which is adopt by him repr an order of 
thought rather than a success of time and may be consid a the 
first attempt to frame a philosophi of histori 

the first of these declin state is timocraci or the govern of 
soldier and lover of honour which answer to the spartan state thi 
is a govern of forc in which educ is not inspir by the 
muse but impo by the law and in which all the finer element of 
organ have disappear the philosoph himself ha lost the 
love of truth and the soldier who is of a simpler and honest natur 
rule in hi stead the individu who answer to timocraci ha some 
notic qualiti he is describ a ill educ but like the 
spartan a lover of literatur and although he is a harsh master to hi 
servant he ha no natur superior over them hi charact is 
base upon a reaction against the circumst of hi father who in 
a troubl citi ha retir from polit and hi mother who is 
dissatisfi at her own posit is alway urg him toward the life 
of polit ambit such a charact may have had thi origin and 
ind livi attribut the licinian law to a feminin jealousi of a 
similar kind but there is obviou no connect between the manner 
in which the timocrat state spring out of the ideal and the mere 
accid by which the timocrat man is the son of a retir statesman 

the two next stage in the declin of constitut have even le 
histor foundat for there is no trace in greek histori of a 
politi like the spartan or cretan pa into an oligarchi of wealth 
or of the oligarchi of wealth pa into a democraci the order of 
histori appear to be differ first in the homer time there is 
the royal or patriarch form of govern which a centuri or two 
later wa succeed by an oligarchi of birth rather than of wealth and 
in which wealth wa onli the accid of the hereditari poss of 
land and power sometim thi oligarch govern gave way to a 
govern base upon a qualif of properti which accord to 
aristotl s mode of use word would have been call a timocraci 
and thi in some citi a at athen becam the conduct medium to 
democraci but such wa not the necessari order of success in state 
nor ind can ani order be discern in the endless fluctuat of 
greek histori like the tide in the euripu except perhap in the 
almost uniform tendenc from monarchi to aristocraci in the earliest 
time at first sight there appear to be a similar inver in the 
last step of the platon success for tyranni instead of be the 
natur end of democraci in earli greek histori appear rather a a 
stage lead to democraci the reign of peisistratu and hi son is 
an episod which come between the legisl of solon and the 
constitut of cleisthen and some secret cau common to them all 
seem to have led the greater part of hella at her first appear 
in the dawn of histori e g athen argo corinth sicyon and nearli 
everi state with the except of sparta through a similar stage of 
tyranni which end either in oligarchi or democraci but then we must 
rememb that plato is describ rather the contemporari govern 
of the sicilian state which altern between democraci and tyranni 
than the ancient histori of athen or corinth

plato in a hyperbol and serio comic vein exagg the folli of 
democraci which he also see reflect in social life to him democraci 
is a state of individu or dissolut in which everi one is do 
what is right in hi own eye of a peopl anim by a common spirit 
of liberti rise a one man to repel the persian host which is the 
lead idea of democraci in herodotu and thucydid he never seem to 
think but if he is not a believ in liberti still le is he a lover 
of tyranni hi deeper and more seriou condemn is reserv for the 
tyrant who is the ideal of wick and also of weak and who 
in hi utter helpless and suspici is lead an almost 
imposs exist without that remnant of good which in plato s 
opinion wa requir to give power to evil book i thi ideal of 
wick live in helpless miseri is the rever of that other 
portrait of perfect injust rule in happi and splendour which

and is also the rever of the king whose rule of life is the good of 
hi subject 

each of these govern and individu ha a correspond 
ethic gradat the ideal state is under the rule of reason not 
extinguish but harmon the passion and train them in virtu 
in the timocraci and the timocrat man the constitut whether of the 
state or of the individu is base first upon courag and secondli 
upon the love of honour thi latter virtu which is hardli to be 
esteem a virtu ha supers all the rest in the second stage of 
declin the virtu have altogeth disappear and the love of gain

extravag of charact is in realiti onli a state of weak and 
dissip at last one monster passion take poss of the whole 
natur of man thi is tyranni in all of them excess the excess first 
of wealth and then of freedom is the element of decay

to return you rememb what wa said of the democrat that he wa the

anim 

and how doe such an one live nay that you must tell me well then

thi is our first proof the second is deriv from the three kind 
of pleasur which answer to the three element of the soul reason 
passion desir under which last is comprehend avar a well a 
sensual appetit while passion includ ambit parti feel love 
of reput reason again is sole direct to the attain of 
truth and careless of money and reput in accord with the 
differ of men s natur one of these three principl is in the

hi own pleasur and depreci those of other the money maker will

other pleasur necessari rather than good now how shall we decid 
between them is there ani better criterion than experi and 
knowledg and which of the three ha the truest knowledg and the 
widest experi the experi of youth make the philosoph 
acquaint with the two kind of desir but the avarici and the 
ambiti man never tast the pleasur of truth and wisdom honour he 
ha equal with them they are judg of him but he is not judg 
of them for they never attain to the knowledg of true be and hi 
instrument is reason wherea their standard is onli wealth and honour 
and if by reason we are to judg hi good will be the truest and so we 
arriv at the result that the pleasur of the ration part of the soul 
and a life pa in such pleasur is the pleasantest he who ha a 
right to judg judg thu next come the life of ambit and in the 
third place that of money make 

twice ha the just man overthrown the unjust onc more a in an 
olympian contest first offer up a prayer to the saviour zeu let 
him tri a fall a wise man whisper to me that the pleasur of the wise 
are true and pure all other are a shadow onli let u examin thi 
is not pleasur oppo to pain and is there not a mean state which 
is neither when a man is sick noth is more pleasant to him than 
health but thi he never found out while he wa well in pain he 
desir onli to cea from pain on the other hand when he is in an 
ecstasi of pleasur rest is pain to him thu rest or cessat 
is both pleasur and pain but can that which is neither becom both 
again pleasur and pain are motion and the absenc of them is rest 
but if so how can the absenc of either of them be the other thu 
we are led to infer that the contradict is an appear onli and 
witcheri of the sen and these are not the onli pleasur for there 
are other which have no prece pain pure pleasur then is not the 
absenc of pain nor pure pain the absenc of pleasur although most of 
the pleasur which reach the mind through the bodi are relief of 
pain and have not onli their reaction when they depart but their 
anticip befor they come they can be best describ in a simil 
there is in natur an upper lower and middl region and he who pa 
from the lower to the middl imago that he is go up and is alreadi 
in the upper world and if he were taken back again would think 
and truli think that he wa descend all thi ari out of hi 
ignor of the true upper middl and lower region and a like 
confu happen with pleasur and pain and with mani other thing 
the man who compar grey with black call grey white and the man who 
compar absenc of pain with pain call the absenc of pain pleasur 
again hunger and thirst are inanit of the bodi ignor and folli 
of the soul and food is the satisfact of the one knowledg of the 
other now which is the purer satisfact that of eat and drink 
or that of knowledg consid the matter thu the satisfact of 
that which ha more exist is truer than of that which ha le the 
invari and immort ha a more real exist than the variabl 
and mortal and ha a correspond measur of knowledg and truth the 
soul again ha more exist and truth and knowledg than the bodi 
and is therefor more realli satisfi and ha a more natur pleasur 
those who feast onli on earthli food are alway go at random up 
to the middl and down again but they never pa into the true upper 
world or have a tast of true pleasur they are like fat beast 
full of gluttoni and sensual and readi to kill one anoth by reason 
of their insati lust for they are not fill with true be and 
their vessel is leaki gorgia their pleasur are mere shadow of 
pleasur mix with pain colour and intensifi by contrast 
and therefor inten desir and men go fight about them a 
stesichoru say that the greek fought about the shadow of helen at 
troy becau they know not the truth 

the same may be said of the passion element the desir of 
the ambiti soul a well a of the covet have an inferior 
satisfact onli when under the guidanc of reason do either of the 
other principl do their own busi or attain the pleasur which is 
natur to them when not attain they compel the other part of the 
soul to pursu a shadow of pleasur which is not their and the more 
distant they are from philosophi and reason the more distant they will 
be from law and order and the more illu will be their pleasur 
the desir of love and tyranni are the farthest from law and those 
of the king are nearest to it there is one genuin pleasur and two 
spuriou one the tyrant go beyond even the latter he ha run away 
altogeth from law and reason nor can the measur of hi inferior 
be told except in a figur the tyrant is the third remov from the 
oligarch and ha therefor not a shadow of hi pleasur but the 
shadow of a shadow onli the oligarch again is thrice remov from 
the king and thu we get the formula 3 x 3 which is the number of a 
surfac repr the shadow which is the tyrant s pleasur and 
if you like to cube thi number of the beast you will find that the 
measur of the differ amount to 729 the king is 729 time more

the most notic point in the 9th book of the republ are 1 the 
account of pleasur 2 the number of the interv which divid the 
king from the tyrant 3 the pattern which is in heaven 

1 plato s account of pleasur is remark for moder and in 
thi respect contrast with the later platonist and the view which are 
attribut to them by aristotl he is not like the cynic oppo 
to all pleasur but rather desir that the sever part of the 
soul shall have their natur satisfact he even agr with the 
epicurean in describ pleasur a someth more than the absenc of 
pain thi is prove by the circumst that there are pleasur which 
have no antec pain a he also remark in the philebu such a 
the pleasur of smell and also the pleasur of hope and anticip 
in the previou book he had made the distinct between necessari 
and unnecessari pleasur which is repeat by aristotl and he now 
observ that there are a further class of wild beast pleasur 
correspond to aristotl s greek he dwell upon the rel and 
unreal charact of sensual pleasur and the illu which ari out 
of the contrast of pleasur and pain point out the superior of 
the pleasur of reason which are at rest over the fleet pleasur 
of sen and emot the pre emin of royal pleasur is shown by 
the fact that reason is abl to form a judgment of the lower pleasur 
while the two lower part of the soul are incap of judg the 
pleasur of reason thu in hi treatment of pleasur a in mani 
other subject the philosophi of plato is sawn up into quantiti by 
aristotl the analysi which wa origin made by him becam in the 
next gener the foundat of further technic distinct both 
in plato and aristotl we note the illu under which the ancient 
fell of regard the transienc of pleasur a a proof of it 
unreal and of confound the perman of the intellectu 
pleasur with the unchang of the knowledg from which they are 
deriv neither do we like to admit that the pleasur of knowledg 
though more elev are not more last than other pleasur 
and are almost equal depend on the accid of our bodili state 
introduct to philebu 

2 the number of the interv which separ the king from the tyrant

characterist design a a number concern with human life 
becau nearli equiv to the number of day and night in the 
year he is desir of proclaim that the interv between them is

minut of the one at an hour of the other one day in thi court is

differ but thi is not so much a say in home phrase they 
are a thousand mile asund and accordingli plato find the natur

on the eighth day the soul of the pilgrim resum their journey 
and in four day came to a spot whenc they look down upon a line of 
light in colour like a rainbow onli brighter and clearer one day 
more brought them to the place and they saw that thi wa the column 
of light which bind togeth the whole univ the end of the column 
were fasten to heaven and from them hung the distaff of necess 
on which all the heavenli bodi turn the hook and spindl were of 
adam and the whorl of a mix substanc the whorl wa in form 
like a number of box fit into one anoth with their edg 
turn upward make togeth a singl whorl which wa pierc by the 
spindl the outermost had the rim broadest and the inner whorl were 
smaller and smaller and had their rim narrow the largest the fix 
star wa spangl the seventh the sun wa brightest the eighth 
the moon shone by the light of the seventh the second and fifth 
saturn and mercuri were most like one anoth and yellow than the 
eighth the third jupit had the whitest light the fourth mar 
wa red the sixth venu wa in white second the whole had one 
motion but while thi wa revolv in one direct the seven inner 
circl were move in the opposit with variou degr of swift 
and slow the spindl turn on the knee of necess and a siren 
stood hymn upon each circl while lachesi clotho and atropo the 
daughter of necess sat on throne at equal interv sing of 
past present and futur respon to the music of the siren clotho 
from time to time guid the outer circl with a touch of her right

interpret to have said is the true happi of man and ani one a

even though he come last let not the first be careless in hi choic

surpri to u the intol zeal of plato against innov in

timocraci into a popular form of govern 

pa from specul to fact we observ that progress ha been 
the except rather than the law of human histori and therefor we are 
not surpri to find that the idea of progress is of modern rather than 
of ancient date and like the idea of a philosophi of histori is 
not more than a centuri or two old it seem to have arisen out of the 
impress left on the human mind by the growth of the roman empir 
and of the christian church and to be due to the polit and social 
improv which they introduc into the world and still more in 
our own centuri to the ideal of the first french revolut and the 
triumph of american independ and in a yet greater degr to the 
vast materi prosper and growth of popul in england and her 
coloni and in america it is also to be ascrib in a measur to the 
greater studi of the philosophi of histori the optimist tempera of 
some great writer ha assist the creation of it while the opposit 
charact ha led a few to regard the futur of the world a dark 
the spectat of all time and of all exist see more of the 
increa purpo which through the age ran than formerli but to the 
inhabit of a small state of hella the vision wa necessarili limit 
like the valley in which he dwelt there wa no remot past on which hi 
eye could rest nor ani futur from which the veil wa partli lift up 
by the analog of histori the narrow of view which to ourselv 
appear so singular wa to him natur if not unavoid

1 by aristotl in the polit from the side of the law

2 by plato in the law book v from the side of the republ

plato s republ ha been said to be a church and not a state and such 
an ideal of a citi in the heaven ha alway hover over the christian 
world and is embodi in st augustin s de civit dei which is 
suggest by the decay and fall of the roman empir much in the same 
manner in which we may imagin the republ of plato to have been 
influenc by the declin of greek polit in the writer s own age the 
differ is that in the time of plato the degeneraci though certain 
wa gradual and insen wherea the take of rome by the goth 
stir like an earthquak the age of st augustin men were inclin 
to believ that the overthrow of the citi wa to be ascrib to the 
anger felt by the old roman deiti at the neglect of their worship st 
augustin maintain the opposit thesi he argu that the destruct 
of the roman empir is due not to the rise of christian but to 
the vice of pagan he wander over roman histori and over greek 
philosophi and mytholog and find everywh crime impieti and 
falsehood he compar the worst part of the gentil religion with

which led other of the earli christian father to recogn in the

trace the parallel of the kingdom of god that is the histori of the 
jew contain in their scriptur and of the kingdom of the world

futur it need hardli be remark that hi use both of greek and 
of roman historian and of the sacr write of the jew is wholli 
uncrit the heathen mytholog the sybillin oracl the myth 
of plato the dream of neo platonist are equal regard by him a 
matter of fact he must be acknowledg to be a strictli polem or 
controversi writer who make the best of everyth on one side and 
the worst of everyth on the other he ha no sympathi with the old 
roman life a plato ha with greek life nor ha he ani idea of the 
ecclesiast kingdom which wa to ari out of the ruin of the roman 
empir he is not blind to the defect of the christian church and 
look forward to a time when christian and pagan shall be alik brought 
befor the judgment seat and the true citi of god shall appear the 
work of st augustin is a curiou repertori of antiquarian learn and 
quotat deepli penetr with christian ethic but show littl 
power of reason and a slender knowledg of the greek literatur 
and languag he wa a great geniu and a nobl charact yet hardli 
capabl of feel or understand anyth extern to hi own 
theolog of all the ancient philosoph he is most attract by plato 
though he is veri slightli acquaint with hi write he is inclin 
to believ that the idea of creation in the timaeu is deriv from the 
narr in genesi and he is strang taken with the coincid 
of plato s say that the philosoph is the lover of god and 
the word of the book of exodu in which god reveal himself to mose

veri interest manner of the beauti and util of natur and of the

state and of the resurrect of the bodi the book is not realli what 
to most person the titl of it would impli and belong to an age which 
ha pa away but it contain mani fine passag and thought which 
are for all time 

the short treati de monarchia of dant is by far the most remark 
of mediaev ideal and bear the impress of the great geniu in whom 
itali and the middl age are so vividli reflect it is the vision of

and successor of it justifi by the ancient virtu of the roman and

if he had not been condemn by a divin author tribun the

fal analog of natur by misappli quotat from the classic

a more convinc argument still is the miser state of the world

the utopia of sir thoma more is a surpri monument of hi geniu

the citi of the sun written by campanella 1568 1639 a dominican 
friar sever year after the new atlanti of bacon ha mani 
resembl to the republ of plato the citizen have wife and 
child in common their marriag are of the same temporari sort and 
are arrang by the magistr from time to time they do not howev 
adopt hi system of lot but bring togeth the best natur male and 
femal accord to philosoph rule the infant until two year 
of age are brought up by their mother in public templ and sinc 
individu for the most part educ their child badli at the 
begin of their third year they are commit to the care of the 
state and are taught at first not out of book but from paint of 
all kind which are emblazon on the wall of the citi the citi ha 
six interior circuit of wall and an outer wall which is the 
seventh on thi outer wall are paint the figur of legisl and 
philosoph and on each of the interior wall the symbol or form 
of some one of the scienc are delin the woman are for the most 
part train like the men in warlik and other exerci but they 
have two special occup of their own after a battl they and the 
boy sooth and reliev the wound warrior also they encourag them 
with embrac and pleasant word some element of the christian or 
cathol religion are preserv among them the life of the apostl is 
greatli admir by thi peopl becau they had all thing in common 
and the short prayer which jesu christ taught men is use in their 
worship it is a duti of the chief magistr to pardon sin and 
therefor the whole peopl make secret confess of them to the 
magistr and they to their chief who is a sort of rector 
metaphysicu and by thi mean he is well inform of all that is go 
on in the mind of men after confess absolut is grant to 
the citizen collect but no one is mention by name there 
also exist among them a practic of perpetu prayer perform by 
a success of priest who chang everi hour their religion is 
a worship of god in triniti that is of wisdom love and power 
but without ani distinct of person they behold in the sun the 
reflect of hi glori mere graven imag they reject refu to 
fall under the tyranni of idolatri 

mani detail are given about their custom of eat and drink about 
their mode of dress their employ their war campanella look 
forward to a new mode of educ which is to be a studi of natur 
and not of aristotl he would not have hi citizen wast their time 
in the consid of what he call the dead sign of thing he 
remark that he who know one scienc onli doe not realli know that 
one ani more than the rest and insist strongli on the necess of a 
varieti of knowledg more scholar are turn out in the citi of the 
sun in one year than by contemporari method in ten or fifteen he 
evid belief like bacon that henceforward natur scienc will 
play a great part in educ a hope which seem hardli to have 
been realiz either in our own or in ani former age at ani rate the 
fulfil of it ha been long defer 

there is a good deal of ingenu and even origin in thi work and 
a most enlighten spirit pervad it but it ha littl or no charm 
of style and fall veri far short of the new atlanti of bacon 
and still more of the utopia of sir thoma more it is full of 
inconsist and though borrow from plato show but a superfici 
acquaint with hi write it is a work such a one might expect 
to have been written by a philosoph and man of geniu who wa also a 
friar and who had spent twenti seven year of hi life in a prison of 
the inquisit the most interest featur of the book common to 
plato and sir thoma more is the deep feel which is shown by the 
writer of the miseri and ignor prevail among the lower class 
in hi own time campanella take note of aristotl s answer to plato s 
commun of properti that in a societi where all thing are common no 
individu would have ani motiv to work arist pol he repli that 
hi citizen be happi and content in themselv they are requir 
to work onli four hour a day will have greater regard for their 
fellow than exist among men at present he think like plato that if 
he abolish privat feel and interest a great public feel will 
take their place 

other write on ideal state such a the oceana of harrington in 
which the lord archon mean cromwel is describ not a he wa 
but a he ought to have been or the argeni of barclay which is an 
histor allegori of hi own time are too unlik plato to be worth 
mention more interest than either of these and far more platon 
in style and thought is sir john eliot s monarchi of man in which 
the prison of the tower no longer abl to be a politician in the 
land of hi birth turn away from polit to view that other citi 
which is within him and find on the veri threshold of the grave that 
the secret of human happi is the masteri of self the chang of 
govern in the time of the english commonwealth set men think 
about first principl and gave rise to mani work of thi class the 
great origin geniu of swift owe noth to plato nor is there 
ani trace in the conver or in the work of dr johnson of ani 
acquaint with hi write he probabl would have refut plato 
without read him in the same fashion in which he suppo himself to 
have refut bishop berkeley s theori of the non exist of matter 
if we except the so call english platonist or rather neo platonist 
who never understood their master and the write of coleridg 
who wa to some extent a kindr spirit plato ha left no perman 
impress on english literatur 

7 human life and conduct are affect by ideal in the same way that 
they are affect by the exampl of emin men neither the one nor 
the other are immedi applic to practic but there is a virtu 
flow from them which tend to rai individu abov the common 
routin of societi or trade and to elev state abov the mere 
interest of commerc or the necess of self defenc like the 
ideal of art they are partli frame by the omiss of particular 
they requir to be view at a certain distanc and are apt to fade 
away if we attempt to approach them they gain an imaginari distinct 
when embodi in a state or in a system of philosophi but they still 
remain the vision of a world unreal more strike and obviou to 
the ordinari mind are the exampl of great men who have serv their 
own gener and are rememb in anoth even in our own famili 
circl there may have been some one a woman or even a child in 
whose face ha shone forth a good more than human the ideal then 
approach nearer to u and we fondli cling to it the ideal of the 
past whether of our own past life or of former state of societi ha 
a singular fascin for the mind of mani too late we learn that 
such ideal cannot be recal though the recollect of them may 
have a human influenc on other time but the abstract of 
philosophi are to most person cold and vacant they give light without 
warmth they are like the full moon in the heaven when there are no 
star appear men cannot live by thought alon the world of sen is 
alway break in upon them they are for the most part confin to a 
corner of earth and see but a littl way beyond their own home or place 
of abod they do not lift up their eye to the hill they are not 
awak when the dawn appear but in plato we have reach a height from 
which a man may look into the distanc and behold the futur of the 
world and of philosophi the ideal of the state and of the life of 
the philosoph the ideal of an educ continu through life and 
extend equal to both sex the ideal of the uniti and correl 
of knowledg the faith in good and immort are the vacant form of 
light on which plato is seek to fix the eye of mankind 

8 two other ideal which never appear abov the horizon in greek 
philosophi float befor the mind of men in our own day one seen more 
clearli than formerli a though each year and each gener brought 
u nearer to some great chang the other almost in the same degr 
retir from view behind the law of natur a if oppress by them 
but still remain a silent hope of we know not what hidden in the 
heart of man the first ideal is the futur of the human race in thi 
world the second the futur of the individu in anoth the first is 
the more perfect realiz of our own present life the second 
the abneg of it the one limit by experi the other 
transcend it both of them have been and are power motif of 
action there are a few in whom they have taken the place of all earthli 
interest the hope of a futur for the human race at first sight seem 
to be the more disinterest the hope of individu exist the more 
egotist of the two motif but when men have learn to resolv 
their hope of a futur either for themselv or for the world into the 
will of god not my will but thine the differ between them fall 
away and they may be allow to make either of them the basi of their 
life accord to their own individu charact or tempera there 
is a much faith in the will to work for an unseen futur in thi 
world a in anoth neither is it inconceiv that some rare natur 
may feel hi duti to anoth gener or to anoth centuri almost 
a strongli a to hi own or that live alway in the presenc of god 
he may realiz anoth world a vividli a he doe thi 

the greatest of all ideal may or rather must be conceiv by u under 
similitud deriv from human qualiti although sometim like the 
jewish prophet we may dash away these figur of speech and describ 
the natur of god onli in neg these again by degr acquir a 
posit mean it would be well if when medit on the higher 
truth either of philosophi or religion we sometim substitut one 
form of express for anoth lest through the necess of languag 
we should becom the slave of mere word 

there is a third ideal not the same but akin to these which ha a 
place in the home and heart of everi believ in the religion of christ 
and in which men seem to find a nearer and more familiar truth 
the divin man the son of man the saviour of mankind who is the 
first born and head of the whole famili in heaven and earth in whom 
the divin and human that which is without and that which is within the 
rang of our earthli faculti are indissolubl unit neither is thi 
divin form of good wholli separ from the ideal of the christian 
church which is said in the new testament to be hi bodi or at 
varianc with those other imag of good which plato set befor u we 
see him in a figur onli and of figur of speech we select but a few 
and those the simplest to be the express of him we behold him in 
a pictur but he is not there we gather up the fragment of hi 
discour but neither do they repr him a he truli wa hi 
dwell is neither in heaven nor earth but in the heart of man 
thi is that imag which plato saw dimli in the distanc which when 
exist among men he call in the languag of homer the like 
of god the like of a natur which in all age men have felt to be 
greater and better than themselv and which in endless form whether 
deriv from scriptur or natur from the wit of histori or from 
the human heart regard a a person or not a a person with or 
without part or passion exist in space or not in space is and 
will alway continu to be to mankind the idea of good

the scene is laid in the hou of cephalu at the piraeu and the whole 
dialogu is narrat by socrat the day after it actual took place to 
timaeu hermocr critia and a nameless person who are introduc 
in the timaeu 




book i 

i went down yesterday to the piraeu with glaucon the son of ariston 
that i might offer up my prayer to the goddess bendi the thracian 
artemi and also becau i want to see in what manner they would 
celebr the festiv which wa a new thing i wa delight with the 
process of the inhabit but that of the thracian wa equal 
if not more beauti when we had finish our prayer and view the 
spectacl we turn in the direct of the citi and at that instant 
polemarchu the son of cephalu chanc to catch sight of u from a 
distanc a we were start on our way home and told hi servant to 
run and bid u wait for him the servant took hold of me by the cloak 
behind and said polemarchu desir you to wait 

i turn round and ask him where hi master wa 

there he is said the youth come after you if you will onli wait 

certainli we will said glaucon and in a few minut polemarchu 
appear and with him adeimantu glaucon s brother niceratu the son 
of nicia and sever other who had been at the process 

polemarchu said to me i perceiv socrat that you and your 
companion are alreadi on your way to the citi 

you are not far wrong i said 

but do you see he rejoin how mani we are 

of cour 

and are you stronger than all these for if not you will have to remain 
where you are 

may there not be the altern i said that we may persuad you to 
let u go 

but can you persuad u if we refu to listen to you he said 

certainli not repli glaucon 

then we are not go to listen of that you may be assur 

adeimantu ad ha no one told you of the torch race on horseback in 
honour of the goddess which will take place in the even 

with hor i repli that is a novelti will horseman carri torch 
and pa them one to anoth dure the race 

ye said polemarchu and not onli so but a festiv will be 
celebr at night which you certainli ought to see let u rise soon 
after supper and see thi festiv there will be a gather of young 
men and we will have a good talk stay then and do not be perver 

glaucon said i suppo sinc you insist that we must 

veri good i repli 

accordingli we went with polemarchu to hi hou and there we found 
hi brother lysia and euthydemu and with them thrasymachu the 
chalcedonian charmantid the paeanian and cleitophon the son of 
aristonymu there too wa cephalu the father of polemarchu whom i 
had not seen for a long time and i thought him veri much age he wa 
seat on a cushion chair and had a garland on hi head for he had 
been sacrif in the court and there were some other chair in the 
room arrang in a semicircl upon which we sat down by him he salut 
me eagerli and then he said 

you don t come to see me socrat a often a you ought if i were 
still abl to go and see you i would not ask you to come to me but 
at my age i can hardli get to the citi and therefor you should come 
often to the piraeu for let me tell you that the more the pleasur 
of the bodi fade away the greater to me is the pleasur and charm 
of conver do not then deni my request but make our hou your 
resort and keep compani with these young men we are old friend and 
you will be quit at home with u 

i repli there is noth which for my part i like better cephalu 
than conver with age men for i regard them a travel who 
have gone a journey which i too may have to go and of whom i ought to 
enquir whether the way is smooth and easi or rug and difficult 
and thi is a question which i should like to ask of you who have 
arriv at that time which the poet call the threshold of old age is 
life harder toward the end or what report do you give of it 

i will tell you socrat he said what my own feel is men of my 
age flock togeth we are bird of a feather a the old proverb say 
and at our meet the tale of my acquaint commonli is i cannot 
eat i cannot drink the pleasur of youth and love are fled away 
there wa a good time onc but now that is gone and life is no longer 
life some complain of the slight which are put upon them by relat 
and they will tell you sadli of how mani evil their old age is the 
cau but to me socrat these complain seem to blame that which 
is not realli in fault for if old age were the cau i too be old 
and everi other old man would have felt a they do but thi is not 
my own experi nor that of other whom i have known how well i 
rememb the age poet sophocl when in answer to the question how 
doe love suit with age sophocl are you still the man you were 
peac he repli most gladli have i escap the thing of which you 
speak i feel a if i had escap from a mad and furiou master hi 
word have often occur to my mind sinc and they seem a good to 
me now a at the time when he utter them for certainli old age ha 
a great sen of calm and freedom when the passion relax their hold 
then a sophocl say we are freed from the grasp not of one mad 
master onli but of mani the truth is socrat that these regret 
and also the complaint about relat are to be attribut to the 
same cau which is not old age but men s charact and temper for 
he who is of a calm and happi natur will hardli feel the pressur of 
age but to him who is of an opposit disposit youth and age are 
equal a burden 

i listen in admir and want to draw him out that he might go 
on ye cephalu i said but i rather suspect that peopl in gener 
are not convinc by you when you speak thu they think that old 
age sit lightli upon you not becau of your happi disposit but 
becau you are rich and wealth is well known to be a great comfort 

you are right he repli they are not convinc and there is 
someth in what they say not howev so much a they imagin i 
might answer them a themistocl answer the seriphian who wa abu

neither of u would have been famou and to those who are not rich and 
are impati of old age the same repli may be made for to the good 
poor man old age cannot be a light burden nor can a bad rich man ever 
have peac with himself

that is true he said

ye he said i have been convinc by the argument a i believ that 
ani one el would have been 

and yet no mention ha been made of the greatest prize and reward

than of the whole

prove it

listen then 

i am attend 

there is a thing which you call good and anoth which you call evil

element is the evil and the save and improv element the good 

ye

and anyth which is infect by ani of these evil is made evil and 
at last wholli dissolv and dy 

true

good nor evil 

certainli not 

if then we find ani natur which have thi inher corrupt 
cannot be dissolv or destroy we may be certain that of such a 
natur there is no destruct 

that may be assum 

well i said and is there no evil which corrupt the soul

review unright intemp coward ignor 

but doe ani of these dissolv or destroy her and here do not let u 
fall into the error of suppo that the unjust and foolish man when 
he is detect perish through hi own injust which is an evil 
of the soul take the analog of the bodi the evil of the bodi is a

ye 

consid the soul in like manner doe the injust or other evil which

from the bodi 

certainli not 

and yet i said it is unreason to suppo that anyth can perish 
from without through affect of extern evil which could not be 
destroy from within by a corrupt of it own 

it is he repli 

consid i said glaucon that even the bad of food whether 
stale decomposit or ani other bad qualiti when confin to 
the actual food is not suppo to destroy the bodi although if the 
bad of food commun corrupt to the bodi then we should say
